channel.title: Songs on lwcas
channel.description: Recent content in Songs on lwcas

item.title: #1: lady (hear me tonight) by modjo
item.author: lwcasgc@gmail.com (lwcas)
item.description:
ironically, i remember listening to this music very often days after breaking up with my last girlfriend.

i’d go home from college riding my bike and wondering what i did wrong.

i feel like it’s supposed to be a love song, but to me it has always been somewhat melancholic through it’s melody and the context i’ve created for it.
item.content:encoded:
ironically, i remember listening to this music very often days after breaking up with my last girlfriend.

i’d go home from college riding my bike and wondering what i did wrong.

i feel like it’s supposed to be a love song, but to me it has always been somewhat melancholic through it’s melody and the context i’ve created for it.

item.title: #2: eyeless by slipknot
item.author: lwcasgc@gmail.com (lwcas)
item.description:
i wasn’t much of a rock/metal fan when i was young. i grew up in a somewhat religious family where anything that deviated from friendly and soothing songs was considered demonic and not to be appreciated.

now that i’m grown and living my own life, i’ve taken the time to listen to music i never explored before. this band stood out to me first because of the masks, but the songs on their first album were exactly what i needed at that moment in my life.
item.content:encoded:
i wasn’t much of a rock/metal fan when i was young. i grew up in a somewhat religious family where anything that deviated from friendly and soothing songs was considered demonic and not to be appreciated.

now that i’m grown and living my own life, i’ve taken the time to listen to music i never explored before. this band stood out to me first because of the masks, but the songs on their first album were exactly what i needed at that moment in my life.

they provided a way to channel stress and express hatred towards people who actually deserve it, instead of the “always forgive everything” mentality i experienced growing up.

i now think that feeling hatred or disliking someone isn’t objectively wrong. of course, it’s not about having unjustified hate for everyone, it’s just that sometimes you can allow yourself to dislike people and/or their actions.

item.title: #3: crutch by aftermud
item.author: lwcasgc@gmail.com (lwcas)
item.description:
as i explored metal music and discovered what i liked about it, i found out about this band from my city. i checked out their first work, an ep that included this song, and i instantly enjoyed it. it might be hard to understand the lyrics, but i got used to them.

this was the first song i wanted to learn on drums, and i actually did learn it. to me, it’s symbolic that with enough practice, i can learn any song. i also really enjoy the main riff.
item.content:encoded:
as i explored metal music and discovered what i liked about it, i found out about this band from my city. i checked out their first work, an ep that included this song, and i instantly enjoyed it. it might be hard to understand the lyrics, but i got used to them.

this was the first song i wanted to learn on drums, and i actually did learn it. to me, it’s symbolic that with enough practice, i can learn any song. i also really enjoy the main riff.

i saw them live earlier this year, and they were all very chill, it was a great time. i’m not interested in going to these types of venues anymore, but it was an interesting experience for sure.

item.title: #4: ac√©phale by xnomadx
item.author: lwcasgc@gmail.com (lwcas)
item.description:
this was one of my favorite songs for a long time. i was devastated to find out the band has ended.

this song is one of the first i listened to when discovering metalcore, and it stood out with its many different melodies that are all very good, and the drumming that’s quite intense yet fun to listen to and practice. i’m not quick enough to play it yet, but it’d be a dream to be able to play it perfectly.
item.content:encoded:
this was one of my favorite songs for a long time. i was devastated to find out the band has ended.

this song is one of the first i listened to when discovering metalcore, and it stood out with its many different melodies that are all very good, and the drumming that’s quite intense yet fun to listen to and practice. i’m not quick enough to play it yet, but it’d be a dream to be able to play it perfectly.

when i listened to it for the first time, i remember being in ecstasy with the 2:55 part because of how the tension kept increasing. i didn’t know what to expect after that much tension, then i got surprised with a beautiful and soothing part at 3:38 that’s engraved in my brain and will be for a long time. definitely an unforgettable song.
